comment.author: 66546790@N07
comment._content: A cruiser on the left is the Austro-Hungarian "Leopard". She vizited Sydney 30.12.1900 – 17.01.1901.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66546790@N07] That makes MUCH BETTER sense! I had been bothered by the St Marys Cathedral Tower in the background (dedicated in 1900). So the fine foreground vessel is NOT HMS UNDINE or the RUBY which sank ten years before. I wonder what it is? And the date of the regatta - Friday, 4 January 1901 as part of the Federation celebrations. Read All About It - SMH 5/1/1900 p.9 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14381619

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
From the above article, worth quoting as it vividly describes this photo -
" ... ... H.M. transport Britannic, B. F. Hayes, Lieutenant li N.R., commanding, and H.M.S. Aberdeen, Captain A. Robb, were the flagships for the occasion, and they were crowded with ladies and gentlemen, particularly the grand old transport No 62, and both vessels were gaily decorated with flags. The Royal Arthur and other war steamers in Farm Cove were also dressed in gala attire, and presented a very pretty sight. All the big steam vessels of the mercantile marine, including the Grosser Kurfürst, the Ortona, the Rome, and the Pacifique looked extremely well. The Karrakatta, of the auxiliary squadron, and the Austrian man-o'-war Leopard were moored pretty close to the flagship Britannic, and formed a considerable addition to the general effect of the scene, The hot westerly breeze was certainly very trying to the spectators on board the Britannic, which was crowded, but the members of the executive committee and Commander Hayes and his officers, also Purser H. I. Thorpe, did everything possible to make the visitors comfortable. During the afternoon many non-competitive sailing and rowing boats put in an appearance at Neutral Bay, and as a number of the larger sailing craft had their sails fringed with flags, the display, though not unique to residents of the city, presented a delightful panorama which was constantly changing and developing new features every few minutes. The "white wings" were evidently out for an exhibition cruise, and as there was plenty of wind to keep them going there was no want of animation in tho vicinity of the two flagships. At 2 o'clock bis Excellency Admiral Pearson with a party of friends boarded the Britannic, ... ..."

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66546790@N07] Thanks for the ID on the various vessels - extremely helpful! [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Thanks for the extra info, lots of details in the image make sense now :)
